snippet: Even with extensive precautions, gene-altered plants turn up in unwanted places regularly enough that farmers have come to consider a few of them weeds.
abstract: Scientists remain mystified over how genetically engineered wheat strain found in Oregon farmer's fields got there, although few are surprised; genetically altered plants turn up in unwanted places regularly enough, even with extensive precautions, that experts say boom in so-called transgenic crops should prompt even more careful evaluation of future varieties with an eye to possibility that they, too, could appear elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Even with extensive precautions, gene-altered plants turn up in unwanted places regularly enough that farmers have come to consider a few of them weeds.

headline.seo: Genetically Altered Crop in Oregon No Surprise
headline.main: Genetically Altered Wheat in Oregon Comes as No Surprise
headline.print_headline: Genetically Altered Wheat in Oregon Comes as No Surprise
